column4: I often do well in science courses
column5: I identify with students who do well on exams and quizzes in science courses
column6: I expect to receive an A- or higher in this course
column7: I am confident I can do the work required for this course
column8: I am often able to help my classmates with physics in small group settings
column9: I usually don't worry about my ability to solve physics problems
column10: When I come across a tough physics problem, I work at it until I solve it
column11: I know how to explain my answers to in-class questions in a way that helps others understand my answer
column12: My peers know how to explain their answers to in-class questions in a way that helps me understand their answer
column13: Listening to my neighbors talk about their answers increases my confidence when responding to the same in-class question a second time
column14: Practice answering in-class questions makes it easier for me to do physics problems at home
column16: I get a sinking feeling when I think of trying to tackle difficult physics problems
column17: I like reading questions and comments that other students have about the material
column18: I am usually confident that I can convince my neighbor of my answer to in-class questions
column19: I am usually confident of my answers to the in-class questions before I talk to a neighbor
column20: When I am solving a physics problem, I try to decide what would be a reasonable value for the answer
column21: I think about the physics I experience in everyday life
column22: It is useful for me to do lots and lots of problems when learning physics
column23: After I study a topic in physics and feel that I understand it, I have difficulty solving problems on the same topic
column24: I am not satisfied until I understand why something works the way it does
column25: I study physics to learn knowledge that will be useful in my life outside of school
column26: If I want to apply a method used for solving one physics problem to another problem, the problems must involve very similar situations
column27: Nearly everyone is capable of understanding physics if they work at it
column28: Doing well on physics exams basically means being able to recall something you've read or been shown
column29: To understand physics I discuss it with friends and other students
column30: I do not spend more than five minutes stuck on a physics problem before giving up or seeking help from someone else
column31: If I don't remember a particular equation needed to solve a problem on an exam, there's nothing much I can do (legally!) to come up with it
column32: In doing a physics problem, if my calculation gives a result very different from what I’d expect, I’d trust the calculation rather than going back through the problem
column33: In physics, it is important for me to make sense out of formulas before I can use them correctly
column35: I want others to see me as a physics person
column36: Learning physics changes my ideas about how the world works
column37: To learn physics, I only need to memorize solutions to sample problems
column38: Reasoning skills used to understand physics can be helpful to me in my everyday life
column39: Spending a lot of time understanding where formulas come from is a waste of time
column40: Your intelligence is something about you that you can't change very much
column41: To understand physics, I sometimes think about my personal experiences and relate them to the topic being analyzed
column42: I can usually figure out a way to solve physics problems
column43: If I get stuck on a physics problem, there is no chance I’ll figure it out on my own
column44: The subject of physics has little relation to what I experience in the real world
column45: You can learn new things, but you can't really change your basic intelligence
